qa_pair.question: Is this considered a holographic sight? Is there a difference in reflex and holographic?
qa_pair.answer: Unlike a laser or red dot sights (reflex), the holographic image projects no forward light onto the target and thus no position revealing light. The projected reticle is only visible by the operator. The operator remains completely hidden downrange even against night vision systems.

qa_pair.question: Are all .22 pellet rifles one shot? Why?
qa_pair.answer: Since they are air powered, all the air is expelled on each shot (for pump-up style rifles). For break barrel style pellet guns, it's not possible to load more than one because the action of breaking the barrel down is what compresses spring to make the shot, and there's no way to get another pellet into the barrel until you break it down. If you want a repeating rifle, you'll probably have to go for a CO2 powered gun.

So be aware that this is not intended as a toy for children. This is a rifle, not a toy. The only reason they call it an "Air Rifle" is that there are different laws already in existence for air rifles, so it stops idiotic lawmakers from dreaming up new and potentially different regulations and laws for spring operated rifles.

qa_pair.question: what is the measurement of the bottom grippers at there widest point before compression?   Can they be locked in place on rail using the allen screws?
qa_pair.answer: Heres how it works - you fit the spring loaded adapter inside the mounting jaws of the weaver based device [scope mount,etc,]. Then you place the whole works onto the top of gun with the teeth of the adapter inserted into the dovetail grooves. Then you tighten the jaws of the mount with its own screws till all is firmly held in the dovetail.

rewrite.edit: You will fit the spring loaded adapter into the mounting jaws of the weaver based device. Then you place the whole works onto the top of the gun with the adapter inserted into the dovetail grooves. Then you tighten the mount with it's own screws.

The adapters are locked into place by fitting them into the mounting jaws of a weaver based device, followed by placing the entire unit on top of the gun with the product's teeth aligned with the grooves. Secure the mount with its own screws.

The product can be fitted with the spring loader adapter inside the mounting jaws of the weaver based device. Then you place it onto the top of the gun with the teeth of the adapter inserted into the grooves.

qa_pair.question: How to tighten the adapter - i don't see the bolts????
qa_pair.answer: There are no bolts, this is an insert which you slip inside the larger weaver style scope ring to reduce it down to fit 3/8 or 11 mm dovetailed receivers.There are two spring loaded alignment pins in between the two halves to keep them lined up with each other.It is the most compact adapter on the market at this time and adds the least height to the scope installation.

The adapter does not use bolts to tighten it, the product inserts into a Weaver-style scope ring, which allows it to fit 3/8 or 11 mm dovetail receivers. Alignment pins between the unit's two halves to ensure alignment.

summary: This product comes as one pair of adapters and can be bought as a pair of two. The adapters are locked into place by fitting them into the mounting jaws of a weaver based device, followed by placing the entire unit on top of the gun with the product's teeth aligned with the grooves. Secure the mount with its own screws. This item will work on a 22 caliber Browning pump rifle's factory groves. However, mounting a large sight to a single adapter won't secure it to the grooves, so it is advised to use 2 adapters. This product is intended for 11 mm dovetail receivers, and therefore should fit a CZ-455.

qa_pair.answer: Honestly it's a pain to set up but not any more of a pain then setting up a typical tent. Like the other person said, not on beach long enough unless you are on a cruise that stays at a port for more than one day.

qa_pair.question: What would be the maximum range for relatively accurate shots for someone that is a relative novice?  Looking for residenc defense.  Need minimum 40'.
qa_pair.answer: The relative novice portion of your question causes me pause.  If you can shoot the stock Glock sights well at 40', meaning that you are able to acquire a good sight picture, stay focused on the front sight, have good trigger control and follow through, then the big dot sights will do their part just fine for you.  Otherwise, please seek some training with a qualified professional.  They helped me alot.

qa_pair.question: Are these tritium front and rear? Will the Big Dot fit in most holsters?

I haven't had any issued with the two different holsters that I've used my 30S in.  I think you should be fine.  I do love these sights, they are fast acquiring and I don't think the tritium is too bright to be distracting or over powering in a night time situation.  Good luck.  Oh, they are also a breeze to install.  Comes with everything you need from tools to loctite.

qa_pair.answer: I have the ones with front and rear tritium.  I wouldn't get the ones without tritium rear, if you do then you basically defeat the purpose of having night sights.  The rear tritium allows you to line up the sights quickly in low light/no light situations.

qa_pair.question: Does this bench support a right angle (90 degree) setting for the back?  Has anyone got Body Beast experience with this bench?
qa_pair.answer: Does NOT support a true right angle.  If you read the description it states "near vertical".  There is a slight decline - you will not notice if you are doing seated shoulder laterals or bicep curls BUT if you do any sort of shoulder presses you will notice that you are leaning back every so slightly. It is a tough piece of equipment but if you want a try 90 degree angle this bench is not it.

qa_pair.question: Can this work with a 25-06
qa_pair.answer: Only if you get the dies for it! There is enough headroom with this press to handle pretty much any cartridge a sporting rifle has ever been chambered for so long as it can be done with standard 7/8"-14 dies. The press can handle the length of the .50 Browning, but since the diameter of that round requires 1 1/4" diameter dies, it's a no-go. Who can think of any cartridge longer than a .50 Browning that one would ever handload?

qa_pair.question: This press has a very tight spot when pulling the handle down about half way and in the same spot on the way back up. Any ideas to free it up?
qa_pair.answer: Does this happen without any brass?  If so it may be that the press linkage bolts are too tight loosen them 1/4 turn.  If it happens while you are running brass through your resizing die then you need to apply a thin coat of case lube to your brass.  Even the tungsten carbide dies need a little lube on the brass occasionally.  The tight spots are normal as your resizing the brass so basically you are bending metal and that takes a bit of pressure.

summary: This press can fit four standard rcbs dies in the turret. The press's rod is metal. The component at the base is plastic. A safety prime is not included with purchase of the press. All standard 7/8 threaded dies fit in the press. The press cannot be converted to work with a three hole.  The turret ring would not support a three ring turret. You have to buy the dies for the specific ammo. The press does not come with the tool for de-priming spent cases. This press will work with a 25-06 if you get the dies for it. There is enough headroom with this press to handle most cartridge.

qa_pair.question: Is the trigger pull more comparable to a 1911 with this connector, rather than a standard Glock pull that stacks at the end?
qa_pair.answer: No, it still has that two-stage feel with the initial take up, a wall, and then the click. The minus connector makes the wall a bit lighter and smoother to get through, that's all.

rewrite.edit: The trigger has a two-stage feel with the initial take up, a wall, and then click.
The pull of the tigger still has the two stage fell. With the initial take up, a wall then a click. The minus connector makes the wall up a bit lighter and smoother to get through.
This product doesn't make the trigger pull on a 1911 comparable to a Glock but allows for the wall to seem easier to get through when using this product.

qa_pair.question: Is the trigger pull more comparable to a 1911 with this connector, rather than a standard Glock pull that stacks at the end?
qa_pair.answer: It stacks noticeably less but the take-up and over-travel remain unchanged. After market connectors are available to eliminate the over-travel, but the take-up remains. I like the minus connector, but it is definitely no 1911 trigger.

qa_pair.question: Is the trigger pull more comparable to a 1911 with this connector, rather than a standard Glock pull that stacks at the end?
qa_pair.answer:
I think of a 1911 as minimal take up or stacking, just a wall, and smooth/clean break. I think of a standard/dot connector as fair amount of take up, initial wall, creep, creep, creep, bang. A minus connector seems more like a fair amount of take up, and the initial wall is there but no stacking/creep but more of a steady pulling through to the bang. Some describe it as squishy, in a way I could see that. A sponge squishes evenly down without any stacking of resistance, this connector is a more even pull and no substantial stacking like there is in a dot connector. In reading the other responses, they describe it very well and with less words, Kudos to them :) .

qa_pair.question: Is the trigger pull more comparable to a 1911 with this connector, rather than a standard Glock pull that stacks at the end?
qa_pair.answer: I myself do not own an 1911 so I can't really compare the two, what I can tell you is this connector makes the trigger pull noticeably lighter and more crisp. this is a great addition to any Glock pistol

qa_pair.question: Is the trigger pull more comparable to a 1911 with this connector, rather than a standard Glock pull that stacks at the end?
qa_pair.answer: To me this connector helped smooth out the pull, but will never compare to the consistent start to finish pull a 1911 has. It also gave me a shorter reset.

qa_pair.question: Is the trigger pull more comparable to a 1911 with this connector, rather than a standard Glock pull that stacks at the end?
qa_pair.answer: The trigger feels the same just reduced to 4 or 4.5lb,will have the same travel and reset. You will have to go with an after market kits to duplicate a 1911 trigger in the Glock, fine for target shooting would not recommend for CCW or Duty carry. Hope this helps.

qa_pair.question: Is the trigger pull more comparable to a 1911 with this connector, rather than a standard Glock pull that stacks at the end?
qa_pair.answer: This connector simply lightens the trigger pull. So you will still have the half inch "take up" before you hit the break. I installed this on a Glock 19 that i carry, and it along with using some Flitz polish on certain contact points really made a big difference. The closest trigger that you can install on a Glock to shoot like a 1911 would be the Travis Haley "Skimmer" trigger. You can check it out at Glocktriggers.com here : http://www.glocktriggers.com/products/haley/

qa_pair.question: Is the trigger pull more comparable to a 1911 with this connector, rather than a standard Glock pull that stacks at the end?
qa_pair.answer: It's still a Glock trigger, fairly crisp and a bit lighter pull.  It takes some tuning to achieve anything close to a 1911 trigger and it's really not a fair comparison

qa_pair.question: Is the trigger pull more comparable to a 1911 with this connector, rather than a standard Glock pull that stacks at the end?
qa_pair.answer: You will never get a Glock trigger like a 1911 as each pull has to pull the striker back, but if you use a 3.5lb connector with a 6lb trigger spring you can get a shorter and lighter trigger pull that gets it as close as possible without having to get too far into the weeds as in changing striker springs and recoil springs.

qa_pair.question: Is the trigger pull more comparable to a 1911 with this connector, rather than a standard Glock pull that stacks at the end?
qa_pair.answer: The 1911's trigger feel is unique to its single action only trigger. The connector will feel very similar. It will just break with less pressure.

This product only holds one pellet because it is a break barrel. This item could kill a coyote or a raccoon and doesn't take long to sight it and shoot. You can sight and shoot quickly since it doesn't require any pumping.

qa_pair.question: does the bolt move? does it preform in a similer fashion to the real thing?
qa_pair.answer: Yes! The bolt cycles as if ejecting shells, this is why two CO2 cyl. are are needed! CO2 is also what drives the bolt back with each shot. If the rifle took only one CO2 cyl. you wouldn't be able to fire as many shots. Although the rifle is more lightweight than the real one the bolt cycle gives it the feel of a real M-14. It even has a slight kick caused by the bolt action!

This gun's bolt  ==DOES NOT== cycle itself nor do you have to cock the gun with the bolt! Source: The Daisy Company, the maker of the M14 replica 4.5mm steel BB and/or .177 pellet firing airgun. The purpose of the TWO 12 gram CO2 cylinders is to enhance the FPS rate although CHRONY findings [and using two brand new CO2 cylinders] DOES NOT support the Daisy cited 700 FPS rate. I bought this gun because of nostalgia reasons since I was issued the real one in 1968 at Fort Dix BCT in the US Army. A very accurate weapon and the replica is also accurate when adjusted properly. Metal would have been preferred over this wholly plastic version but then too, an all  metal version would have greatly increased the cost. I can still hear that BCT echo today, you know, the shouted "Keep your hands off the trigger and keep the weapon pointed down range!"  ;-)  I didn't see the replacement M16 until AIT although I knew guys later on in service who actually preferred the M14 over the M16!

qa_pair.question: Does brass require you to tumble after the sonic cleaning or is it good to go for reloading?
qa_pair.answer: Only if you want it nice and shiny.

rewrite.edit: If you want it nice and shiny.
nice and shiny.require you to tumble after the sonic
Tumble is not required after sonic cleaning on brass, unless extra shining is desired.

qa_pair.question: Does brass require you to tumble after the sonic cleaning or is it good to go for reloading?
qa_pair.answer: While you could probably go ahead and reload after cleaning/drying, I like to run mine through a corncob cleaning to get some polish back on the brass. I use the sonic cleaner to get the worst of the carbon off, then tumble to make it pretty.

qa_pair.question: Does brass require you to tumble after the sonic cleaning or is it good to go for reloading?
qa_pair.answer: I say yes, tumble it, brass comes out clean, but dark and blotchy.Also make sure you dry them out very well, water stays in the primer area, and if you load a primer with moisture in it, it will kill the primer.  Tumbling will help with this.

qa_pair.question: Does brass require you to tumble after the sonic cleaning or is it good to go for reloading?
qa_pair.answer: I personally sonic clean and, after drying,  tumble my brass. This is just a matter of personal preference. Looks like almost new when finished.

qa_pair.question: Does brass require you to tumble after the sonic cleaning or is it good to go for reloading?
qa_pair.answer: It will be clean enough to reload, but it won't necessarily be shiny. Tumbling after sonic cleaning will make them shiny. So it just depends on your standards.

qa_pair.question: Does brass require you to tumble after the sonic cleaning or is it good to go for reloading?
qa_pair.answer: If you want shiny/new brass then tumble them.  I always do along with just a bit of polish and the brass comes out looking like new, even on 10 times reloaded brass.

qa_pair.question: Does brass require you to tumble after the sonic cleaning or is it good to go for reloading?
qa_pair.answer: Brass needs to be thoroughly rinsed, toweled and dried. Air drying takes about 2-3 days unless you have a hand dryer. I leave mine on the towel and roll them around once or twice, it keeps the water spots down.

summary: The distributor claims that the hydro flask will fit the 32oz wide mouth and both the 40 oz and 64 oz hydro flask. The cap does indeed fit the 64 oz Lifeline insulated steel growler. The cap is leakproof like Contigo bottles, however the ice will not stay solid as long as it does with the original lid. The flexible ring around the neck allows the flat cap to just pop off and a straw is able to be placed in the lid. The cap can be placed on the top rack of the dishwasher. There is a removable silicone gasket around the inner edge.

qa_pair.question: does this work on airsoft
qa_pair.answer: Does the gun on question have a rail? If not you can't mount the sight. You need a MIL-STD rail for this to mount. After that you're fine. Most AEGs modeled after the M4/AR-15/M16 platform will have the type of rail this mounts to.It should also be noted that this was designed for the AR platform so Airsfoft is nothing to this sight.

qa_pair.question: does this work on airsoft
qa_pair.answer: Yup, it'll work on any AEG with a rail.  In fact, if you take the time to zero it in before the game starts, I think you'll find it's surprisingly effective.  I would recommend getting a reflex sight screen protector to go with it -- I see a lot of guys with sights similar to this with cracks because they took a BB right to the glass part of the sight.

summary: You need a MIL-STD rail for this to mount. Most AEGs modeled after the M4/AR-15/M16 platform will have the type of rail this mounts to. The dimensions are 3 1/8 in long over all, the height is 2 1/8 in, and the rail is 2 1/4 in long. It's set up for a Picatinny rail and works with a weaver. The dial on the right hand side should be turned to the letter R.
